story: Treasury gives up on chasing £.bn of public cash stolen by Covid fraudstersLabour branded the revelations outrageous as it emerged £ in every £ taken by scammers would likely never be recoveredChancellor Rishi Sunaks department accepted that billions of pounds Covid cash would never be recovered from fraudsters Image: Frankie MillsByLizzy BuchanDeputy Online Political Editor:,  Jan Updated:,  Jan | commentsMore than £ billion of public cash taken by fraudsters from Covid support schemes has been written off by the Treasury. HMRC figures released last week show £. billion was stolen from pandemic relief schemes such as furlough and self employment support by people claiming cash they werenapost entitled to. A taskforce set up to claw back cash recovered £ million last year, and is expecting to recover an additional £ billion from scammers. This means the Treasury only expects to recover £. billion - or £ of every £ taken - by fraudsters. The figures, first unearthed by the Times, were quietly published last week. Labour branded the figure outrageous and said the Government should have been able to help support workers without losing billions of pounds of taxpayersapos cash. Shadow Chancellor Rachel Reeves told the Mirror: These confessions are outrageous. While prices soar, billions in hard-earned taxpayer cash has been frittered away by fraud - and the Chancellor is happy to shrug his shoulders and lose it forever. It shouldn’t be beyond the wit of government to get money where it needs to go, without allowing fraudsters to steal taxpayer funds. Leaving the till open and unattended for thieves to clear out would be a sackable offence for a shopworker, yet apparently it is acceptable for a Chancellor. And Shadow Business Minister Bill Esterson tweeted: You can bet this Government wouldn’t be so casualit was benefit claims. The Prime Ministeraposs official spokesman said: We introduced these unprecedented Covid support schemes at speed to protect jobs and livelihoods. The result of the action is our economy is back to pre-pandemic levels, we are the first major European economy to report that. He added: Obviously fraud is unacceptable and weaposre taking against those who abuse the system - , ineligible claims blocked, £ million recovered last year, HMRC taskforce is expected to recover an additional £ billion of taxpayersapos money. HMRC boss Jim Harra admitted last year that all the money would likely never be ed. “We will not be able to recover it all, he told the Financial Times. You will reach a point of diminishing s in terms of good use of resources. “These are time-limited schemes. We do need to put them to bed at some stage and move on from them. And   is the year for which our plans go up [to]. Whether there’s anything that goes on beyond that will depend, I think, on what we find and the rate ofthat we’re getting. title: doctor who broke covid rules
story: Doctor who broke Covid rules to cuddle grieving widow outraged by Downing Street partiesDr Prit Buttar, , opened up about his decision to breach social distancing rules to give a heartbroken pensioner a hug during the UKs second lockdown in Dr Prit Buttar admitted he has felt guilty about breaching the rules every dayByKirsty FeerickJournalistLaura SharmanFreelance writer:,  Jan Updated:,  Jan | comments A doctor who was left racked with guilt after breaking Covid rules to comfort a grieving widow was left outraged by the Downing Street parties. Dr Prit Buttar, , revealed how he willingly breached social distancing measures to give a heartbroken pensioner a hug at a vaccine clinic during the second lockdown of .The retired GP, who ed to work during the pandemic, was vaccinating the woman in Annan when she said her husband had just died of cancer. Moved by her sadness, the doctor reached out and held her as she wept in his arms and told him that his hug was the first time anyone had embraced her since her husband’s death. Now Dr Buttar is comparing his own rule-breaking with the the Prime Minister after he was left feeling guilty for just wanting to be human.He told the Daily Record : I did what I felt was the right thing to do when breaking the rules, but to see the leaders of our country twist their drinks parties to be justied is appalling. “People have had to make serious choices when going against Covid rules and I have been feeling guilty for just wanting to be human. “We follow the restrictions because it is the only way out of this and most people, like myself, take that seriously and would only break themthe situation seriously called for it.“So to find out Boris Johnson and others have been having get togethers, and then give us terrible excuses for them, just tipped me over the edge to share my experience.Dr Buttar admitted that he has felt guilty about breaching the rules every day, but was unable to help himself as he watched his patient struggle in her grief. The Scot, who lives near Kirkcudbright, recalled how she spoke of her loneliness during her Covid vaccination appointment just one week after her husbandaposs death. The woman, in her s, had moved from England to Scotland with her husband just before the outbreak of the pandemic but he fell ill a short time later. She was unable to make any friends in her new community during lockdown while busy caring for her sick husband, meaning she was alone when he died.  Dr Buttar added: The bottom line is as I am a doctor and believe in science so I follow the rules but seeing this poor woman, I had to do something. I could tell she wanted to talk, so I abandoned my usual spiel about the vaccine, possible side-effects, and just listened. “She had been so wrapped up in caring for her husband over the past year, she hadn’t had a chance to make friends with local people, something worsened by the first lockdown. “She had dealt with his death and funeral arrangements alone, so I decided to break the rules about social distancing. The health professional recalled leaning forward in his chair and putting his arms around the grieving widow. She clung to me and wept, and sobbed into my shoulder and said aposthis is the first time anyone’s embraced me since he died.’ “I still believe it is so important to follow the rules but I felt this situation called for it.  Dr Buttar has vaccinated almost , people but said this moment really stuck out to him. “I didn’t take comforting that woman lightly just like most other ordinary people who are trying to face our painful reality,” he added. The doctor decided to share his experience and the serious choice he made after being left outraged over the news of the Downing Street parties. Prime Minister Boris Johnson has apologised for attending the Bring Your Own Booze gathering but insisted he thought it could have been technically within the rules. Dr Buttar said: “I came out of retirement to help with vaccines because I have a duty and obligation to help people, which is what I did with this woman. Alsosomeone had challenged me for breaking the rules and fined me I would look them in the eye and askthey wanted cash or a cheque, I would have taken responsibility for my actions like our Prime Minister should now do. He added: To see our leaders and their staff party while we faced this has left me beyond angry. title: happiest unhappiest places uk revealed
story: Happiest and unhappiest places in the UK revealed - is your town on the list A list of the happiest and unhappiest towns and cities in the UK has been revealed - and its all based on how sunny they are.Chichester has been ranked the sunniest place in the UK. Image: Getty ImagesByKatie L Wilson:,  Jan | commentsWith today being Blue Monday, a list of the aposhappiest places in the UKapos has been compiled to help you beat the winter blues. Researchers looked at places that get the most sunlight during winter, to trigger the hormone serotonin to be released into your brain and fight off Seasonal Affective disorder . And itaposs good news for Chichester in West Sussex, which gets  sunlight hours in winter, while Bradford in West Yorkshire is the least sunny, with just .See the full lists below to see where your area ranks.Studies have shown that neurotransmitters, such as serotonin, play a role in regulating a person’s mental health and a decline can be a contributing factor towards the onset of SAD.  Seasonal affective disorder affects more than just your energy levels, explained Neil Wright, a sleep expert at Beds Divans, which commissioned the research. It also affects your sleep and day-to-day le. People with SAD often feel excessively sleepy during the day and typically sleep longer than usual at night. “Healthy sleep helps us balance our moods and regulate our emotions. Without healthy sleep, you’re more likely to struggle with feelings of depression and anxiety. In addition to boosting mood, serotonin can also aid in calming and focusing you and so, by this logic, Brits would be more likely to avoid the ‘winter blues’ in sunnier places.  The aposwinter bluesapos are caused by short and dark days during the winter months. Around two million people in the UK are affected by SAD, with two-fths of UK adults feeling more depressed due to dark nights.The lists were compiled using Met Officeweather data to compare the sunlight hours of each town and city, determining which locations were the best and worst for beating the blues. The study also found that the South East is the sunniest region in the UK, with  cities towns from that region receiving the most hours of natural sunlight, and Yorkshire and the East  West Midlands are the least sunniest regions in the UK, with only  place from each region making it into the list. Sunniest Cities  Towns in the UK Results are based on sunlight hours data from the Met Office .Chichester -  sunlight hours in winter Hastings -  St Helens -  Eastbourne -  Southend-on-Sea -  Poole -  Brighton -  Ipswich -  Peterborough -  Bournemouth - Least Sunny Cities and Towns in the UKBradford -  sunlight hours in winter Barnsley -  Rochdale -  Glasgow -  Paisley -  Belfast -  York -  Gateshead -  Preston  Sevenoaks - Neil added that there are ways to help cope with seasonal fatigue and SAD. A greater focus on self-care may be beneficial. Getting outdoors, exercising regularly, eating energy-boosting foods, and socialising can reduce the onset of SAD symptoms, said Neil. “An abrupt change in your bedtime can do harm to your mental and physical health. If you choose to go to bed earlier over the winter months, we recommend you adjust your bedtime by  hour each day until you reach your intended sleep schedule. This way there’s far more chance of getting a good night’s sleep. “The change in daylight hours can result in people losing their routines. People may begin to sleep in which can affect how youthroughout the day and your sleep schedule. “To keep in sync, you should stick to a routine and resume getting up early despite how dark it is. story: How much should we be worried about Covid post-vaccination heart problems There have been a rare few cases of people developing myocarditis after their Moderna jab, but there is no need to panic, writes the Mirrors Dr Miriam StoppardRare condition in teenagers still gives scaresImage: Getty ImagesopinionByMiriam Stoppard:,  Jan | commentsThe son of a friend of mine, a student aged , developed myocarditis after his first Covid jab. Should he have his second, his mum asked me. Myocarditis is inflammation of the heart muscle, and any mention of a heart problem will scare parents to death, but it’s not as bad as it may seem. Just how dangerous this side effect is still isn’t clear and, according to some experts, it might not be a cause for concern at all.However, the US Food and Drug Administration has paused its approval of Moderna’s vaccine for adolescents – as it is reviewing data from Europe on the risk of myocarditis following mRNA vaccination used to combat Covid.My friend’s son is unlucky. US data shows it’s a very rare condition, occurring in only about  out of a million vaccinations. But according to the EU, Moderna’s shot is more likely to cause this ­inflammation in adolescents. Several Scandinavian countries no longer give Moderna to people under .Do you agree  Have your say in the comment section But there’s good reason for ­optimism. US data from millions of vaccinations show the inflammation, when it occurs, goes away within a matter of days without any serious consequences. Sarah Long, a ­paediatric infectious disease expert at Drexel University College of Medicine, Pennsylvania, US, and a member of the vaccine advisory  of the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention, thinks that the post-vaccine heart inflammation might be dferent from myocarditis from other causes. In fact, it’s so dferent, and less severe than typical myocarditis, she says, that giving it the same name has created unnecessary worry over the condition. “Let’s not call this myocarditis,” Long says. “Give me a patient with vaccine-associated myopericarditis every day over one who has true viral myocarditis.” Long says the inflammation from the vaccine is dferent from other heart inflammations as it isn’t concentrated in the heart muscle itself, it’s in the lining around it – the pericardium. Moreover, the lining isn’t essential for a healthy heart. Long also points out that surgeons sometimes remove it ­altogether during heart ops and patients come to no harm – and the CDC hasn’t recorded a single death from the condition. “In vaccine-related inflammation, everyone was up and running in five days,” says CDC scientist Matthew Oster. Children experiencing chest pain is certainly nothing to be brushed off lightly, says Long. “Nobody has died of myopericarditis, and children are dying of coronavirus,” she says. “So, of course, it’s a risk-benefit ratio that comes out in the direction of vaccination.” Wise words. of Prince Andrew standing beside a teenager who claims she was forced to have sex with the royal shows a mystery thumb in the bottom right corner.Who took the snap of the Duke of York with his arm around the waist of Virginia Gufre, while now-convicted sex trafficker Ghislaine Maxwell grins behind them, has remained a mystery for  years.The photo is reported to have been taken in March  in Maxwellaposs London townhouse, and Prince Andrew claims he doesnapost remember it being taken or that he ever met Ms Gufre, who was then , that evening. The identity of the photo takeraposs thumb has never been revealed and remains unidentied.It comes as Andrew was said to have been left in tears when his mum stripped him of his honorary military titles after a US judge ruled a civil case in New York against Andrew by his sex accuser Ms Giuffre can go ahead. He feels that he has let so many people down, not least his mother, during her Platinum Jubilee year.” Our insider said of the royal’s ­dramatic demotion: “He had hoped that he might get some sort of stay of execution and be allowed to clear his name before his titles were removed.  “There are a number of people in the royal household who are utterly convinced that he is innocent. “But the clamour for Andrew’s scalp meant that a quick and brutal decision needed to be made.” The move, announced in a shock Palace statement on Thursday, left Andrew exiled from official royal le and facing le as a private citizen.  He is also expected to cover his own legal costs for the civil case. He was also told he will no longer be able to use the title of His Royal Highness in any official capacity. The move came after years of damaging speculation arising from Ms Giuffre’s claim she was forced to have sex with the duke three times when she was , including once in London.  Andrew’s plight worsened when his former friend Maxwell, , was found guilty of offences relating to her work as fixer for the Dukeaposs associate Jeffrey Epstein, a conviced paedophile and billionaire.The Duke of York has always denied the allegations and tried to explain his links with Epstein by doing an interview with BBC Newsnight where he claimed he has no recollection of ever meeting Ms Gufre. She alleges that the photo was taken at Maxwellaposs house in Belgravia, central London after a night out at Tramp nightclub in Mayfair. She claims that she was forced to have sex with Andrew on three occasions. In a disastrous BBC Newsnight interview in , the Duke denied those claims. He insisted that an alleged encounter in  did not happen because he spent the day with his daughter, Princess Beatrice, taking her to Pizza Express in Woking, Surrey. A source close to Ms Giuffre’s legal team has now claimed she is determined to “ruin him” because of his “arrogant” behaviour. “No one can believe how badly Andrew and his legal team have messed up. His arrogance is what has destroyed him,” they said. “It is Virginiaaposs firm belief that Andrew should go to jail for what heaposs done but in the end leaving him broke and destroyed may be enough. By the end of the year, we could have a “flu-type” relationship with milder new Covid iants and an end to restrictions, according to SAGE member Prof Mike Tildesley.New cases fell % over the last seven days, with , reported yesterday. title: pub landlord renames boozer the
story: Pub to be renamed The Lying B****** in response to Boris Johnson parties scandalDaniel Davies, who owns what was once the James Atherton pub in New Brighton, near Liverpool, has suggested a new name for the venue, which has previously been called The Three B***endsDaniel’s pub was previously named ‘The Three B***ends’ Image: Getty ImagesByAlice Peacock:,  Jan Updated:,  Jan  A pub landlord with a history of changing the name of his boozer to poke fun at ious political scandals is now to rebrand his venue as “The Lying B****** in a dig at Boris Johnson.Daniel Davies owns what was once the James Atherton pub in New Brighton, near Liverpool. He suggested a new name for the venue as Johnson is facing furious calls to resign, following reports of at least  parties across Downing Street, Whitehall and Tory HQ while millions suffered under lockdown rules. Johnson is accused of attending at least four of the events.Covid-bereaved families have blasted the bashes, and No’s repeated attempts to obscure the truth before the PM finally apologised.Daniel’s pub was previously named The Three B***ends and featured a collage of Boris Johnson, Matt Hancock and Dominic Cummings with bells on their heads in October ,reports.  It was said to be a tongue-in-cheek protest at the Government’s handling of the situation when the Liverpool City Region was placed into Tier Three lockdown, forcing pubs to close. The pub was once again renamed in November , called “The Two Helmets” following Mr Cummings’ departure from Downing St. The image outside of the pub showed the PM and his former health secretary wearing hardhats, as the landlord protested about continuing restrictions on the pub-trade. Daniel pointed out that both Mr Cummings, the PM’s former chief advisor, and Mr Hancock, quit their positions within weeks of the signs going up. “Next name change for the pub ” his tweet asked.  “The first was The Three B***endsNext was The Two HelmetsSo. Two down one to go!” Daniel said the first rebrand was prompted by the government blaming the leisure sector for the spread of Covid-. He previously said his business had been “decimated” and their lack of action had compounded the problem. He said: “Westminster’s further decision to pick and choose which types of venue may open, based on those serving meals for example, is mind-boggling. ‘Whilst the renaming of the pub is clearly tongue in cheek, as far as I’m concerned the gloves are off and ministers need to understand the gravity of the perilous situation they have placed us in.  This is a town that finally feels like it’s on the up and we need funding immediately to protect our businesses and support our staff. Top civil servant Sue Gray is probing a range of the Downing Street parties, spanning May  to April , and is expected to publish a report within days. At the time of all these gatherings, indoor socialising was banned to control the spread of the virus.But ultimately the Prime Minister will get to decide himselfhe has breached the Ministerial Code. Johnson is reportedly planning to force out a string of top staff to save himself in what has been dubbed Operation Big Dog.Speaking to the media today, Conservative party chairman Oliver Dowden said the Prime Minister is remorseful about allegations of Covid rule-breaking and would seek to “address the underlying culture in Downing Street”.There had been failings in No , he admitted, though he denied it was a resigning matter for Boris Johnson. story: Exclusive: Queen may alienate Prince Harryhe continues to act like spoilt child, says expertPrince Harry says hes unable toto the UK with Meghan Markle, Archie and Lilibet due to security risks, but a row has broken out over what protection he should be allowedMeghan and Harry with the Queen in  Image: Getty ImagesByZoe ForseyFeatures Editor:,  Jan Updated:,  Jan | comments The Queen will be irritated by Prince Harryaposs threat to take the Government to court over his security, an expert has claimed.The Duke says heaposs unable toto the UK with we Meghan and their children Archie and Lilibet as it isnapost safe without specialist police protection. The family lost their taxpayer-funded security when the quit the royal family in  and use a private alternative for their new lives in the US. Heaposs wants pay for police assistance when heaposs in the UK - in line with the coupleaposs plan to become financially independent - but the Home Office has rejected this. Harry has now applied for a judicial review against the decision.Ingrid Seward, author of Prince Philip Revealed and Editor in Chief of Majesty magazine, tells the Mirror his latest move wonapost have gone down with the Queen - who is currently dealing with the fallout from Prince Andrewaposs legal case. She explains: Prince Harryaposs threat of legal action against his grandmothers government will not sit kindly with her. The Queen does not like being threatened. Even though the threat is not directed at her personally, it is a threat that comes under her jurisdiction. It will make her annoyed and very irritated. She has no desire to alienate the Duke and Duchess of Sussex , butthey continually behave like spoiled children trying to get their own way, she will be forced to do so. As youngsters both Harry and William knew exactly how their Police Protection Officers operated. They became close to them. They were together every time they left home. One even sat outside the classroom. They were friendly, efficient and unobtrusive. No wonder Harry wants that kind of protection for his we and children. But he is very unlikely to get it. Many have been left wondering what Harryaposs request will mean for his future trips to the UK, with many hoping to catch a glimpse of the Sussexes during the Queenaposs Jubilee celebrations in the summer. Ingrid says: Harry is due back to the UK in the Spring for the service of thanksgiving for the le of his grandfather, Prince Philip. He will be protected during this official engagement at Westminster Abbey. ButHarry and Meghan choose the celebrations of the Platinum Jubilee weekend to make an entry into the UK, as things stand at the present, they will not have round the clock Scotland Yard protection - unless they are with other members of the royal family. If for instance they appeared on the Buckingham Palace balcony they would be afforded all the security necessary along with everyone .But when they drive home to Frogmore Cottage, their private bodyguards will be responsible for them.Once there, they are the responsibility of the Windsor Castle security. The police at Windsor recently apprehended an intruder who had climbed over the security fence. If the Sussexes don’t get their own way as regards their demand for police protection, they may decide not to come to the UK. In spite of the fuss their security risk is low. What they want is protection from photographers trying to get pictures of them and their children. The more they shield their children from public gaze the more of a target they will become. Harry’s father should tell them to let the world see Archie and Lilibet’s faces. After they are his grandchildren too. It is not up to the -year-old Queen to tell Harry how to behave. What would this do for the already tense relations within the family  If it means she never gets to meet Lilibet, it will become Harry and Meghan’s problem for the rest of their lives. And that would be very sad. story: Queens Scottish home vandalised with paedo graffiti as police launch probePhotos taken yesterday morning show Her Majestys Palace of Holyroodhouse in Edinburgh behind an outer wall daubed with graffiti reading, paedo home and burn Tory scumThe Queens Edinburgh palace has been sprayed with the words, paedo homeByRyan FaheyNews Reporter:,  Jan Updated:,  Jan  Police are investigating after a vandal graffitied paedo home on the wall outside the Queen’s Scottish residence.The outer walls of the Palace of Holyroodhouse in Edinburgh were pictured spray-painted with two defamatory remarks yesterday morning.One image shows paedo home sprayed in large white letters along one wall, while the palace can be seen in the background. Another image shows the words burn Tory scum written along the same wall in similar style. The graffiti comes just days after a US court ruled that Virginia Giuffre, who claims that Prince Andrew abused her when she was , could proceed with legal action against him.Prince Andrew has strongly denied the claims. Buckingham Palace released a statement last Thursday saying that The Duke of York would be ing his military titles and royal patronages back to the Queen.Rory Richmond, a law student from Glasgow, posted a photo on Twitter Sunday of the graffiti aimed at the Conservatives.He wrote: “This was photographed at Holyroodhouse in Edinburgh earlier today.“We must condemn and confront the mindless acts of vandalism and hatred.” The tweet has received over  likes and has had dozens of comments and retweets.Social media users were outraged by the graffiti. One wrote: “Appalling vandalism. There are no excuses for it at all, itaposs criminality whether or not it suits your political party of choice.In a statement shared with The Mirror, a Police Scotland spokesperson said: “Police received report of vandalism on an external wall at the Palace of Holyroodhouse in Edinburgh which happened between pm on Saturday,  January and am on Sunday,  January, . “Enquiries are ongoing and anyone with information should contact police via , quoting incident number  of  January.” The prince has been reeling after he was stripped of his military titles and royal patronages just  hours after being told he must face a civil trial. The move means Andrew has been completely removed from official royal le and he now have to face his future as an ­ordinary citizen. The Duke of York was informed that he will no longer use the title of His Royal Highness in any official capacity by the Queen on Thursday. The decision was made after hours of deliberation between senior members of the Firm. But the summit is said to have not been straight-forward, with his lawyer left in the car park and the Prince left stunned by the outcome. Among the key revelation from the meeting, was news of a united front from Prince Charles and Prince William, who were reportedly of the view that the Duke of York has presided over a complete and utter disaster.” Andrew is also said to have been unaware about the plans, with sources describing him as shell-shocked at the move. story: Queen to swerve giving Andrew and Harry a major Platinum Jubilee honour this yearThe Queen is the first monarch to hit the auspicious  year Platinum Jubilee milestone but her favourite child Prince Andrew and grandchild Prince Harry, will now be awarded Jubilee medals, it is reported" content"https:i-prod.mirror incoming article.ece ALTERNATES n _JS.jpg" width"" "" The Queen is the first British monarch to reign for  years Image: WPA Pool Getty ImagesByKaisha LangtonAssistant News Editor:,  Jan The Duke of York and Duke of Sussex will not be awarded Jubilee medals as other members of the Armed Forces are, reports suggest. Around , medals are expected to be awarded to frontline members of the emergency and prison services, as well as the Armed Forces who have completed five yearsapos work.However, Prince Andrew and Prince Harry are not due to be awarded the Queen aposs Platinum Jubilee medal, which will be handed out on February , thereports.The medals are given by the monarch to show her gratitude to the public service of military personnel.Having lost their honorary titles, Andrew and Harry will no longer be eligible for the commemorative medal given to serving members of the Armed Forces, police, fire, emergency and prison services.  Other members of the Royal Family holding honorary positions in the military will however be eligible. The only veterans that will receive the medal are living recipients of the George Cross or Victoria Cross, which means the Dukes of York and Sussex will be treated like all other veterans and not receive the award. The announcement comes days after Prince Andrew was stripped of his military titles and royal patronages. The -year-old royal will also stop using the style His Royal Highness in an official capacity, a royal source said. The news came as he faces a US civil action over sexual assault allegations - claims which he has consistently denied. The Duke of York stepped back from public duties amid controversy in November  over his connection to convicted paedophile Jeffrey Epstein.  In a statement last week, Buckingham Palace said: “With the Queen’s approval and agreement, the Duke of York’s military affiliations and royal patronages have been ed to the Queen. The Duke of York will continue not to undertake any public duties and is defending this case as a private citizen.”The Duke of Sussex stepped back from royal le in  with we Meghan, Duchess of Sussex.Prince Harry was forced to give up three honorary titles following this decision: Captain-General of the Royal Marines, Honorary Air Commandant of RAF Honington and Commodore-in-Chief, Small Ships and Diving, Royal Naval Command.  Non-working members of the Royal Family who do not hold honorary military titles will receive the medal as a gt, according to The . The medals are privately funded and hold commemorative value which means they cannot be worn in public at official events such as Remembrance Day. The Platinum Jubilee is due to include a full roster of events to commemorate  years of the Queen including a four-day Bank Holiday weekend from June -. news uk-news savvy-family-transform-entire-home-"Couple transform their home using dark interiorsByKaty-Rose MeaneyAlahna KindredNews Reporter:,  Jan | commentsA savvyy family have transformed their terraced home with second-hand items, and it cost them less than £..Sonia Bhanot, , created bespoke pieces and found unusual items in second-hand shops as she shared the homeaposs makeover on Instagram.The mum-of-two and her family moved into the s home more than  years ago. Sonia, an alternative therapist and husband Chris, a musician, had decided once their sons were older it was time to show off their iniduality in their home. The couple, from Coventry, filled the four-bed property with artwork, stylish patterns and bold designs - avoiding the cliche aposlight and airyapos look of many minimalist makeovers. They went for darker colours and insist it does not make the house smaller, but provides a cosy home that comes alive in the winter. Sonia said: We moved here in  and it was all beige walls. It was very bland with nothing about it really. But we had two young kids and we didnapost really know what our style was when the boys were little. We never liked the way it was decorated, but when you have young children, itaposs sometimes hard to show your personality at home. We looked into what we wanted our home to be like for us and we ripped up the laminate to find floorboards and found original tiles in the hallway. We started to find quirky features in the house and embraced them. The couple started their top-to-bottom transformation in . Their sons Evan, , and Cassius, , still live in the house. Sonia said: I decorate with my feelings and for us, our home has such a cosy and comforting feel to it. I feel like the lounge hugs you as you walk in. We encompass the darkness and embrace it.I adore the open fire, that sold the house to me and it brings the house alive in winter.Sonia admits friends and family were unsure when they revealed their decorating style but the couple insists using darker colours doesnapost cramp the space. She said: Itaposs not a massive house, no high ceilings and when we said we wanted to go dark with our design ideas people said it will make the room smaller, but honestly thataposs rubbish.  for our daily newsletter to keep up to date with all the essential information atwww.mirror email.She added:People either love it or itaposs too dark for them to live in. She said: A lot of the things in this house I have made, the red tassel lampshade and some artwork.The mannequin heads I found on eBay and turned them into wall planters. She added: My favourite room has to be the living room and one of my favourite features in the house is the fireplace. Our little dining area in the kitchen is so cosy. I hand stencilled the gold stars and I gold leafed the tiles in the kitchen. The kitchen cupboards were fine, but not to our taste so we just changed the handles and painted the front of them. In our dining area, I like to repurpose everything so we repainted our table and chairs. It cost around £ to transform the bathroom and most of that was buying a new toilet seat. Sonia painted the lounge and dining room the same colour to create a flow between the rooms but painted the hallway a light pink and used a grey carpet. She said: Paint was our main expense - and I do like to buy a lot of plants. I like the original s door with glass and wanted to keep the hallway lighter to not lose the feature of the door. We wanted to have lots of artwork on the walls and you can be resourceful, you donapost have to buy new. Sonia added: Your house has to make you smile and feel good that you live there. story: Unpleasant new Omicron symptom that makes you feel nauseous and causes vomitingAmong the wide range of symptoms being linked to the Omicron iant of Covid-, some can be easier to spot than others. Nausea and vomiting are thought to be some of the easiest to separate from the common coldOmicron can cause vomiting in some cases, according to experts Image: Getty Images iStockphotoByHarry Thompson:,  Jan | commentsOmicron continues to rip through the nation, with tens of thousands of new Covid cases being reported each day. While previous iants of the virus have been easy to spot, Omicron is somewhat stealthier, its symptoms blending in with seasonal illnesses like the flu or a common winter lurgy.Older strains, like the Delta iant, tended to see their symptoms focus around shortness of breath, a new and continuous cough and a fever. Meanwhile, Omicron has seen symptoms like a scratchy throat, fatigue and muscle ache rising to the fore as some of the more commonly experienced signs. However, there are some symptoms that arenapost as common amongst these annual nuisances that could make spotting the presence of Omicron in your system easier. Is nausea and vomiting a sign of Omicron  Nausea and vomiting could be a sign your body is working against a Covid- infection, according to Good Housekeeping.They report that healthcare experts are seeing an uptick in the number of people picking up Omicron and having uncontrollable vomiting and nausea as some of their primary symptoms. This makes the symptoms relatively easy to spot compared to a common cold, which is unlikely to cause such a reaction from the body. Good Housekeeping reports that the trends being spotted by researchers who have been looking into the iant between December and January are mapping the virus as attacking the upper respiratory tract. Experts have also warned that Omicron sufferers could still experience regular covid symptoms. It is worth bearing in mind of course that vomiting and nausea donapost necessarily mean you have covid - they are very common symptoms for a wide range of dferent medical conditions. However sickness be an indicator of Omicron in some scenarios.What are the symptoms of Covid- According to the US-based Centers for Disease Control, or CDC, a number of symptoms are now being considered more common. The CDC has updated its list of Covid  symptoms to reflect the presence of Omicron as one of the major iants in the USA. They are: Fever or chills Cough Shortness of breath or dficulty breathing Fatigue Muscle or body aches Headache New loss of taste or smell Sore throat Congestion or runny nose Nausea or vomiting Diarrhoea Meanwhile, the UK-based NHS still lists the three most prevalent symptoms from the previous iants.These are a high temperature, a new cough and a loss or change to your sense of taste and or smell. story: Woman left unable to have kids after docs said she was too young for a smear testHannah Baker had symptoms for more than a year but despite requests for a smear test the procedure was turned because she was under  at the timeHannah Baker and her partner Joe Allaway Image: Hannah Baker  SWNSByLauren BeavisGraeme Murray:,  Jan Updated:,  Jan | commentsA woman who was devastated by cervical cancer was told she was too young for a smear test. Hannah Baker attended appointments and undergone surgical procedures for abdominal pain and bleeding in hospital. But she was distraught after her requests for a smear test were denied because was under  at the time. And now she is unable to have children because she has had cervical cancer. Cervical screening is available to women and people with a cervix aged  to  in England. But Hannah was diagnosed with the disease in March  when she . Now , she instructed specialist medical negligence lawyers at Irwin Mitchell to investigate her care and whether her cancer could have been diagnosed sooner. She is hopeful for a family after lawyers secured a settlement to fund her surrogacy.Frimley Health NHS Foundation trust, carried out an internal investigation and recommended any woman, irrespective of age, who is undergoing cervical cautery, should have a cervix biopsy of the before having treatment.Following legal submissions, the trust has now agreed an undisclosed six-figure settlement but has denied liability. Hannah underwent surgery to safeguard her oies for future fertility treatment before having chemoradiotherapy, radiotherapy and brachytherapy. However, the cancer treatment has left her unable to conceive. The settlement will fund surrogacy as Hannah and her partner Joe Allaway, aged , look to start a family. Hannah has now joined her legal team at Irwin Mitchell in supporting Cervical Cancer Prevention Week and the importance of women having smear tests. Chloe Morgan, specialist medical negligence lawyer at Irwin Mitchell representing Hannah, said: While Hannah has successfully battled cancer the effects of the disease will continue to live with her for the rest of her le. Tragically Hannahaposs only hope of becoming a mum is by surrogacy. Hannah has shown great bravery in sharing her story and her efforts have created changes in the Trustaposs policy with the aim of preventing other women going through similar situations. We join her in supporting Cervical Cancer Prevention Week and raising awareness of the importance of attending screening appointments. Hannah said: For a number of months, my le seemed just to be medical appointments. I knew something wasnapost quite right but it still came as huge shock when I was told I had cancer. At the same time as trying to comprehend I had cancer I was trying to come to terms with the grief of losing my baby and thatI beat the disease Iaposd struggle to be able to conceive and that I needed to save my oies. When I look back I still feel a lot of anger and frustration about what happened and everything Iaposve been through. Iaposm very fortunate that Iaposve had the support of my family and Joe and Iaposm proud of how far Iaposve come considering what Iaposve had to deal with. Having children is something Iaposve wanted ever since I can remember. The thought of one day having a family was a major driver for me in getting through the cancer treatment. Because of what Iaposve been through Iaposm keen to try and raise awareness of cervical cancer to ensure other women donapost have to share my experiences. I was told I was too young for a smear test but I believe theyaposre so important. I would urge women to trust their body and to keep pushing their treating team and ask questionsthey feel they need to or seek a second opinion. story: Woman, , shares little-known Covid side effect which makes it hard to eatA TikToker from Calornia has taken to social media to share how Long Covid has a relatively unknown side effect which makes it dficult for her to swallow or consume foodMarianna Cisnero has shared her Covid journey on TikTok including her long Covid strugglesByKaisha LangtonAssistant News Editor:,  Jan Updated:,  Jan | comments A woman, , suffering from Long Covid since testing positive for the virus in July has struggled to eat ever since.Marianna Cisneros from Calornia, US, has suffered from a condition called dysphasia since contracting the virus. The condition means she has trouble swallowing food. In a TikTok video describing the torturous ailment, she said: Doctors donapost know why. She said it could be down to neurological damage and adding it is a side effect which is not being discussed enough. Marianna, an ICU nurse said there are a few reasons why she may be suffering the condition, including her autonomic nervous system because she has Postural orthostatic tachycardia syndrome , or peripheral neuropathy, which she has on her entire right side. The NHS says common long Covid symptoms include:Fatigue Shortness of breath Chest pain or tightness Problems with memory and concentrationDficulty sleepingHeart palpitations Dizziness Pins and needles Joint pain Depression and anxiety Tinnitus, earaches Feeling sick, diarrhoea, stomach aches, loss of appetite High temperature, cough, headaches, sore throat, changes to sense of smell or taste Rashes  She said: Do you know how torturous it is to be this young and have to drink Ensure for most of your calories and on a good day mashed potatoes  Iaposve been dealing with this for over a year now and Iaposm frustrated because I want to eat. Iaposm hungry a lot of the time and I just canapost because I risk food getting stuck or aspirating on it.The ICU nurse has documented her journey and recovery from Covid on TikTok - starting from when doctors initially believed she had a stroke after testing positive.With so much changing so quickly, keep on top of what is happening with the Mirroraposs news updates by email. Delivered straight to your inbox, our daily coronavirus briefing will keep you informed of what is happening with Covid, lockdown, the vaccination rollout and the impact on how we live.here. Marianna said: I could hardly walk and I was having a lot of weird neurological conditions. Thataposs why I fight so hard to bring awareness to it because a lot of people didnapost believe [me]. The mother-of-three previously shared her struggles with trying to walk after she was diagnosed with Covid. She told NBC San Diego: I did not expect to get knocked down as much as I did.My symptoms from the very beginning started out neurological, I started losing vision in the right eye and I developed pretty high blood pressure.Marianna added: Itaposs just been a whirlwind. Iaposm you know numb on the right side, and sometimes itaposs very dficult to walk. It just comes in waves. I have good days, and I have bad days. Recent Office for National Statistics data shows an estimated . million people living in the UK are suffering from self-reported Long Covid.The figures, valid from November  to December  means around two percent of the UK have the condition. Those at greatest risk of getting self-reported Long Covid including those aged -, females, those living in more deprived areas, those working in health, social care, teaching or education, and those with another activity-limiting health condition or disability. dilemma after her grandmother passed away and left her everything in her will.Although this is not an unusual thing for a grandparent to do, the woman has been left conflicted after her dear grandma left nothing but a single dollar to her dad, who abandoned the family for another woman when she was just  years old.When I was  years old, my mother found out my father was having an affair and he got the other woman pregnant. My dad confessed he was in love with the other woman and wanted to leave my mother, the woman wrote on Redditaposs AITA forum. She obviously heartbroken and didn’t know what to do, as we had moved to a new state with my father for work so she had no family around. My father dropped us like a bad habit, he attempted to keep a relationship with me, but ultimately his new family was aposhis priorityapos as he said. Tough to understand for a  year old, but whatever. If he didn’t want me, I wasn’t going to need him so my mother and I moved on. The only way we were able to move on was with the help of my grandmother, my fatheraposs mother. She always loved us and was appalled with what her son had done to us. He stopped seeing her as well for the most part. Over the years, the woman and her mum became increasingly close with her grandmother, often spending special occasions and holidays together, while her dad was nowhere to be found. Unfortunately, the years caught up with her and she developed colon cancer, advanced late stage. Her decline was rapid. Within a few months she was in hospice, the woman continued.  For more of the news you care about, straight to your inbox, sign up for one of our daily newsletters here. Days before she passed, she asked me to call her son to come see her as she knew her time was coming. He’d only been to see her a couple times since she had gotten sick. When he came by, I was visiting as we did every few days and he acted like I was some random person. Grandma asked him to come back tomorrow, but he said he’d be back in a few days. She passed  days later without him coming back despite my calls and texts to come. She went peacefully with me and my mom by her side. That was hard. I miss her every day. She was myangel most of my le and I know she continues to watch over me. After the funeral and everything took place, the woman and her mum were contacted by her grandmotheraposs lawyer, who revealed she had, in fact, left both her home and , to her in her will. I had no idea she did that, but in the will, there was a note to me from her that said: aposYou are worth it. Love Grandma.apos She’s amazing, the woman added. Also in her will, she left my father exactly  as his inheritance. When he found out, he went ballistic, blowing up my phone all the time demanding I give him aposhis house and his money.apos His new we and his son were messaging me a lot and his son was writing on social media that I manipulated my grandmother.  Eventually, the womanaposs father apologised for his behaviour and explained he was under a lot of stress because heaposs in debt and was expecting a windfall from his mum to help cover his bills and send his son to college, leading her to feel bad and question whether she should share the money after all. Iaposve thought about it a lot and I don’t think I’m going to share anything with him and I kind of think that makes me an a**hole because it seems like they really do need it, but on the other hand f*** him. One Reddit user replied: The reason she left him  was to make it clear to the Court in case he tried to challenge the will, that she hadn’t forgotten to include him, but that she intended to disinherit him. She knew that her son would try to take the money she left you. It is very common practice to leave  when disinheriting someone. Respect your grandmothers wishes and don’t give your father a dime. A second wrote: The reason your grandma gave him exactly  is so that he couldnapost contest it. She did not want him to gain anything from her passing. She knew what she was doing. story: Eerie last photo taken by British woman washed away by Tonga tsunami before waves hitAngela Glover is thought to have been swept away when she was hit by huge waves on one of the islands of Tongas west coast, while trying to save dogs with her husbandAngela Glovers last Instagram post showed the red sky and eerie silence Image: thegloverfits InstagramByKelly-Ann MillsNews Reporter:,  Jan Updated:,  Jan | comments A British woman who is thought to have died in the Tonga tsunami made a heartbreaking final post on social media, before the danger hit.Angela Glover is believed to have been swept away when she was hit by huge waves which crashed into an island on the countryaposs west coast.Shortly before the tsunami happened the -year-old posted a picture of red skies on Instagram, saying she had witnessed a few swells as authorities warned of a tsunami risk in the Polynesian archipelago, which is made up of  islands.She wrote: “We’ve been under tsunami warnings today...everything’s fine... a few swells ....a few eerie silences. Her photo shows the entire sky lit up red as she looked out over a calm ocean. Desperate family members had appealed for help finding Angela Glover, but a body was today found in the search for her. Her brother said she had been attempting to rescue dogs with her husband when huge waves battered the island, where she had lived since .  Angela, who ran a dog sanctuary in Tongaaposs capital, Nukuaposalofa, was swept away as the island was hit by ft waves on the west coast of Tongatapu, the countryaposs main island. Her husband James was able to cling on to a tree, and it is believed he later discovered Angelaaposs body. Speaking outside the family home in Sussex, her brother Nick Eleini said the family was devastated by the tragedy. “She was beautul. She was a ray of sunshine, he said.  She would just walk into a room and lighten the room up and she loved her le, both when she was working in London and then she achieved her le’s dream of going to work in the south Pacic. “She always wanted to swim with whales - that was a childhood ambition and that is what drove her to Tonga but she loved her le there and we are so proud of her achievements in Tonga with both her and James starting a business and creating a le there are her charity work with Tonga Animal Welfare Society. She was so committed to it.“She loved animals and dogs particularly.The uglier the dog, the more she loved it. We would laugh at her when she sent us these photos on Facebook of dogs she had rescued. She was a lovely girl and she was the centre of our family.We’re just broken.” He said Angela had been washed away with four or five dogs who she was walking at the time. The couple were housesitting a home on the west coast of the island. In a statement Mr Eleini added: “Angela and James loved their le in Tonga and adored the Tongan people, in particular they loved the Tongan love of family and Tongan culture. Family friend Donna Head, posted on Facebook : “The worst news possible has been confirmed by family members. Our Ange did not survive the Tonga Tsunami.“I have no words other than I’m utterly heartbroken and numb. May our beautul friend rest in peace. Ange, I will look out for your mum, I promise. Good night, God bless angel.” New Zealand and Australia have despatched military surveillance flights to Tonga to assess the damage. title: man who betrayed anne frank
story: Man who betrayed Anne Frank and family to Nazis unveiled  years after her deathA new investigation has identied a suspect who may have betrayed Jewish diarist Anne Frank and her family to the Nazis during the Second World WarThe Diary of Anne Frank published after her death is the most famous first-hand account of Jewish le during the war Image: Reuters Hand OutByJames Murray:,  Jan | comments The man who betrayed Anne Frank and her family to the Nazis appears to have finally been outed,  years after the diarist’s death.A painstaking probe has led to Jewish lawyer Arnold van den Bergh being named as the one who exposed the Franks’ secret hideaway in Amsterdam. Former FBI agent Vincent Pankoke was part of the -strong team of investigators who revealed the “well-known notary” as the guilty party. Their detective work has been chronicled by author Rosemary Sullivan in her book The Betrayal of Anne Frank. The investigation into van den Bergh began in  when a filmmaker and Dutch journalist began trying to find the betrayer and they brought Mr Pankoke on board.  He worked closely with Ms Sullivan and Monique Koemans, a senior advisor to the Dutch government. A list of suspects was narrowed down to  and eventually one. Ms Sullivan said: “We looked at each person and it was in terms of opportunity, motive and knowledge.” They also examined the findings of two previous investigations. Among the documents was a letter sent anonymously to Otto, who died in  aged , which said van den Bergh had revealed his hiding place. When the investigators found the note van den Bergh is alleged to have handed to the Nazis there were no names on it so it could be argued he did not know the identity of those in hiding. Despite the Frank family’s tragic end, Ms Sullivan urges readers not to view van den Bergh, who died in , too harshly. She said: “I don’t think anybody can judge van den Bergh unless they were in his situation…you knew your children were going to be exterminated, to give away an address with no name – it mitigates. “He did not turn over information out of wickedness or for self-enrichment as so many others had. Like Otto Frank’s, his goal was... to save his family.” And Mr Pankoke believes van den Bergh’s identity had remained secret for so long because of fears it would incite anti-Semitism. “Perhaps it was just felt it’ll only stoke the fires further,” he told CBS  Minutes. story: NASA discovers new Jupiter-sized planet which is  times bigger than EarthThe gas giant was found by Tom Jacobs who was checking Nasa data from the Transiting Exoplanet Survey Satellite and was confirmed by two academicsDubbed TOI- b, the planet was found by Citizen Scientist Tom Jacobs Image: NASA JPL-Caltech R. HurtByAntony Thrower:,  Jan | commentsA new planet with three times the mass of Jupiter has been discovered in the galaxy. Dubbed TOI- b, the planet was found by Citizen Scientist Tom Jacobs using data collected by Nasa’s Transiting Exoplanet Survey Satellite . The gas giant orbits its stars in just  days- compared to Jupiter which takes around  Earth years to travel around our Sun. The discovery was reported in the Astronomical Journal. Tom found TO having taken part in the Planet Hunter initiative which looks at the collected data. He spotted something irregular in February  and flagged it to two scientists, who later confirmed the find. He said: “Discovering and publishing TOI- b was a great group effort demonstrating that professional astronomers and seasoned citizen scientists can successfully work together.  “It is synergy at its best.” Scientists say the planet is around  lightyears away from Earth and has around  earth masses of elements heavier than hydrogen and helium. Around , exoplanets have been confirmed with billions more suspected to be in our galaxy. Paul Dalba, from the University of Calornia, Riverside, added: “The manual effort that they put in is really important and really impressive because it’s actually hard to write code that can go through a million light curves and identy single transit events reliably,” “This is one area where humans are still beating code.” It comes as an asteroid bigger than any building on Earth is set to soar past the planet tomorrow. It has been named and is more than a kilometre wide at , metres- making it bigger than the worldaposs tallest building the Burj Khala in Dubai which is  metres . However, it poses no threat to Earth and when it passes it will still be more than five times the moonaposs distance from the planet. news world-news speedy-border-collie-zooms-after-"Border Collie runs all the way around edge of field to get ballByBethan ShufflebothamNiche Writer:,  Jan | commentsBorder collies are undeniably one of the most intelligent working breeds - from herding sheep, to even learning names of their toys. And while some dogs might enjoy a quick game of fetch, others don’t realise when their owners have thrown the ‘invisible’ ball.But Tipsy goes the extra mile - quite literally - to chase her beloved ball.When her owner Jessi Burk, from London, in Canada, showed Tipsy her ball, she stopped dead in her tracks, paws poised and ready. title: tonga volcano aerial photos show
story: Tonga volcano: Aerial photos show island split in two by tsunami after eruptionThe underwater volcano erupted near the Pacic nation of Tonga and the extent of the damage can now be seen from space after it wreaked havoc on SaturdayNow the true extent of the damage can be seen from spaceByLaura SharmanFreelance writer:,  Jan Updated:,  Jan | commentsShocking images show the aftermath of an underwater volcano which erupted in the South Pacic Ocean on Saturday.Satellite images have revealed the extent of the damage after the Hunga Tonga-Hunga Ha’apai volcano erupted, with the devastation visible from space.The event triggered a tsunami and sent waves crashing into homes on the island, which was blanketed with toxic ash. The Red Cross said it was preparing to respond to what it called the worst volcanic eruption the Pacic has experienced in decades. Up to , people could have been affected by the tsunami, according to Katie Greenwood of the charity. One British woman was reported missing after trying to save her dogs with her husband and getting washed away by a wave. Angela Glover, who runs a dog rescue shelter on the island, was swept away with the animals while her husband James managed to hold onto a tree, according to New Zealand state broadcaster TVNZ. Tsunami warnings and evacuation orders were also triggered in neighbouring countries, including Japan and the east coast of Australia. Hunga-Tonga-Hunga-Haaposapai has erupted regularly over the past few decades but the impact of Saturdayaposs blast was felt as far away as Japan and the United States. Australia and New Zealand sent surveillance flights on Monday to assess damage in Tonga, isolated from the rest of the world. Initial reports suggest no mass casualties took place form Saturdayaposs eruption and tsunami, according to Australiaaposs Minister for the Pacic Zed Seselja. But Australian police had visited beaches and reported signicant damage with houses thrown around.  We know there is some signicant damage, and know there is signicant damage to resorts, Mr Seselja said adding that Tongaaposs airport appeared to be in relatively good condition. Surveillance flights will assess the situation in outer islands where communication is completely cut off. Tongaaposs deputy head of mission in Australia, Curtis Tuaposihalangingie, asked for patience as Tongaaposs government decides its priorities for aid.The nation is concerned about the risk of aid deliveries spreading Covid- to the island, which is currently free from the virus.We donapost want to bring in another wave - a tsunami of Covid-, Mr Tuaposihalangingie said. When people see such a huge explosion they want to help.  He went on to highlight how Tonga diplomats were also concerned by some private fundraising efforts and urged the public to wait until a disaster relief fund was announced. Any aid sent to Tonga would need to be quarantined, and it was likely no foreign personnel would be allowed to disembark aircraft, he said. The eruption of the Hunga-Tonga-Hunga-Haaposapai volcano triggered a tsunami on the shores of Tonga and cut off phone and internet lines for the entire island. International communication has been severely hampered by damage to an undersea cable which could take more than a week to restore. Australia and New Zealand were assisting with satellite calls, he said.  Telephone networks in Tonga have been restored but ash was posing a major health concern, contaminating drinking water. Most people are not aware the ash is toxic and bad for them to breath and they have to wear a mask, Tuaposihalangingie said.The Haaposatafu Beach Resort,  miles outside the capital Nukuaposalofa, was completely wiped outaposapos, the owners said on Facebook.The family that manages the resort had run for their lives through the bush to escape the tsunami, it said. The whole western coastline has been completely destroyed along with Kanukupolu village,aposapos the resort said. Two people drowned off a beach in Northern Peru due to high waves caused by the tsunami. More than a day after the eruption, countries thousands of kilometres to the west have volcanic ash clouds over them, New Zealand forecaster WeatherWatch said. Early data suggests the eruption was the biggest blast since Mount Pinatubo in the Philippines  years ago, New Zealand-based volcanologist Shane Cronin told Radio New Zealand. This is an eruption best witnessed from space, Cronin said. We will deliver you more content, live news as it happens, as well as breaking crime news and the latest from court, together in one place. story: We are excited to announce a new home for the Evening Express content online, with a bigger and better website in partnership with The Press and Journal. We have spoken to our readers, and our aim is to deliver you everything that you need to know, together in one place.If you are a subscriber or thinking about joining our digital community, find out what it means for you below.In order to give you access to the news that you need, we have expanded our newsrooms and created dedicated news teams to serve you and our extended local communities across Aberdeen, Aberdeenshire, the Highlands and Islands and the North and North-East of Scotland. We will deliver you more content, live news as it happens, as well as breaking crime news and the latest from court, together in one place. We have also found new ways of telling our stories online, from in-depth investigations through to full- documentaries and podcasts.There is no change to The Press and Journal and the Evening Express newspaper or ePapers. The newspapers will continue to be available for purchase at your local store, delivered to your home, or as an ePaper . We will continue to deliver you the best stories in print, that you have come to expect from the PJ and the Evening Express.Our ePapers are a full replica version of the newspaper, published online,  days a week. You can access the PJ and the Evening Express ePaper via our dedicated ePaper apps where you can save and share stories, access all the paper supplements easily via their dedicated menu and even play interactive puzzles!If you would like to find out more about subscribing to the PJ or the Evening Express ePaper, please contact our Digital News Subscriptions Team on Your subscription to the Press and Journal will allow you to access all of the Evening Express stories which are now available on the PJ website. All of the best Evening Express content, including columnists and football analysis will now appear on the PJ website and will be available for you as part of your subscription.If you have an ePaper subscription there will be no change as to how you access your Press and Journal ePaper.The new website is now live. story: We are excited to announce a new home for the Evening Express content online, with a bigger and better website in partnership with The Press and Journal. We have spoken to our readers, and our aim is to deliver you everything that you need to know, together in one place.If you are a subscriber or thinking about joining our digital community, find out what it means for you below.In order to give you access to the news that you need, we have expanded our newsrooms and created dedicated news teams to serve you and our extended local communities across Aberdeen, Aberdeenshire, the Highlands and Islands and the North and North-East of Scotland. We will deliver you more content, live news as it happens, as well as breaking crime news and the latest from court, together in one place. We have also found new ways of telling our stories online, from in-depth investigations through to full- documentaries and podcasts.There is no change to The Press and Journal and the Evening Express newspaper or ePapers. The newspapers will continue to be available for purchase at your local store, delivered to your home, or as an ePaper . We will continue to deliver you the best stories in print, that you have come to expect from the PJ and the Evening Express.Our ePapers are a full replica version of the newspaper, published online,  days a week. You can access the PJ and the Evening Express ePaper via our dedicated ePaper apps where you can save and share stories, access all the paper supplements easily via their dedicated menu and even play interactive puzzles!If you would like to find out more about subscribing to the PJ or the Evening Express ePaper, please contact our Digital News Subscriptions Team on Your subscription to the Press and Journal will allow you to access all of the Evening Express stories which are now available on the PJ website. story: We are excited to announce a new home for the Evening Express content online, with a bigger and better website in partnership with The Press and Journal. We have spoken to our readers, and our aim is to deliver you everything that you need to know, together in one place.If you are a subscriber or thinking about joining our digital community, find out what it means for you below.In order to give you access to the news that you need, we have expanded our newsrooms and created dedicated news teams to serve you and our extended local communities across Aberdeen, Aberdeenshire, the Highlands and Islands and the North and North-East of Scotland. We will deliver you more content, live news as it happens, as well as breaking crime news and the latest from court, together in one place. We have also found new ways of telling our stories online, from in-depth investigations through to full- documentaries and podcasts.There is no change to The Press and Journal and the Evening Express newspaper or ePapers. The newspapers will continue to be available for purchase at your local store, delivered to your home, or as an ePaper . We will continue to deliver you the best stories in print, that you have come to expect from the PJ and the Evening Express.Our ePapers are a full replica version of the newspaper, published online,  days a week. You can access the PJ and the Evening Express ePaper via our dedicated ePaper apps where you can save and share stories, access all the paper supplements easily via their dedicated menu and even play interactive puzzles!If you would like to find out more about subscribing to the PJ or the Evening Express ePaper, please contact our Digital News Subscriptions Team on Your subscription to the Press and Journal will allow you to access all of the Evening Express stories which are now available on the PJ website. story: We are excited to announce a new home for the Evening Express content online, with a bigger and better website in partnership with The Press and Journal. We have spoken to our readers, and our aim is to deliver you everything that you need to know, together in one place.If you are a subscriber or thinking about joining our digital community, find out what it means for you below.In order to give you access to the news that you need, we have expanded our newsrooms and created dedicated news teams to serve you and our extended local communities across Aberdeen, Aberdeenshire, the Highlands and Islands and the North and North-East of Scotland. We will deliver you more content, live news as it happens, as well as breaking crime news and the latest from court, together in one place. We have also found new ways of telling our stories online, from in-depth investigations through to full- documentaries and podcasts.There is no change to The Press and Journal and the Evening Express newspaper or ePapers. The newspapers will continue to be available for purchase at your local store, delivered to your home, or as an ePaper . We will continue to deliver you the best stories in print, that you have come to expect from the PJ and the Evening Express.Our ePapers are a full replica version of the newspaper, published online,  days a week. You can access the PJ and the Evening Express ePaper via our dedicated ePaper apps where you can save and share stories, access all the paper supplements easily via their dedicated menu and even play interactive puzzles!If you would like to find out more about subscribing to the PJ or the Evening Express ePaper, please contact our Digital News Subscriptions Team on Your subscription to the Press and Journal will allow you to access all of the Evening Express stories which are now available on the PJ website. All of the best Evening Express content, including columnists and football analysis will now appear on the PJ website and will be available for you as part of your subscription.If you have an ePaper subscription there will be no change as to how you access your Press and Journal ePaper.The new website is now live. Evening Express content can now be found on The Press and Journal website.When you purchased your subscription an email was sent to your account with your login details. story: We are excited to announce a new home for the Evening Express content online, with a bigger and better website in partnership with The Press and Journal. We have spoken to our readers, and our aim is to deliver you everything that you need to know, together in one place.If you are a subscriber or thinking about joining our digital community, find out what it means for you below.In order to give you access to the news that you need, we have expanded our newsrooms and created dedicated news teams to serve you and our extended local communities across Aberdeen, Aberdeenshire, the Highlands and Islands and the North and North-East of Scotland. We will deliver you more content, live news as it happens, as well as breaking crime news and the latest from court, together in one place. We have also found new ways of telling our stories online, from in-depth investigations through to full- documentaries and podcasts.There is no change to The Press and Journal and the Evening Express newspaper or ePapers. The newspapers will continue to be available for purchase at your local store, delivered to your home, or as an ePaper . We will continue to deliver you the best stories in print, that you have come to expect from the PJ and the Evening Express.Our ePapers are a full replica version of the newspaper, published online,  days a week. You can access the PJ and the Evening Express ePaper via our dedicated ePaper apps where you can save and share stories, access all the paper supplements easily via their dedicated menu and even play interactive puzzles!If you would like to find out more about subscribing to the PJ or the Evening Express ePaper, please contact our Digital News Subscriptions Team on Your subscription to the Press and Journal will allow you to access all of the Evening Express stories which are now available on the PJ website. All of the best Evening Express content, including columnists and football analysis will now appear on the PJ website and will be available for you as part of your subscription.If you have an ePaper subscription there will be no change as to how you access your Press and Journal ePaper.The new website is now live. Evening Express content can now be found on The Press and Journal website.When you purchased your subscription an email was sent to your account with your login details. story: We are excited to announce a new home for the Evening Express content online, with a bigger and better website in partnership with The Press and Journal. We have spoken to our readers, and our aim is to deliver you everything that you need to know, together in one place.If you are a subscriber or thinking about joining our digital community, find out what it means for you below.In order to give you access to the news that you need, we have expanded our newsrooms and created dedicated news teams to serve you and our extended local communities across Aberdeen, Aberdeenshire, the Highlands and Islands and the North and North-East of Scotland. We will deliver you more content, live news as it happens, as well as breaking crime news and the latest from court, together in one place. We have also found new ways of telling our stories online, from in-depth investigations through to full- documentaries and podcasts.There is no change to The Press and Journal and the Evening Express newspaper or ePapers. The newspapers will continue to be available for purchase at your local store, delivered to your home, or as an ePaper . We will continue to deliver you the best stories in print, that you have come to expect from the PJ and the Evening Express.Our ePapers are a full replica version of the newspaper, published online,  days a week. You can access the PJ and the Evening Express ePaper via our dedicated ePaper apps where you can save and share stories, access all the paper supplements easily via their dedicated menu and even play interactive puzzles!If you would like to find out more about subscribing to the PJ or the Evening Express ePaper, please contact our Digital News Subscriptions Team on Your subscription to the Press and Journal will allow you to access all of the Evening Express stories which are now available on the PJ website. All of the best Evening Express content, including columnists and football analysis will now appear on the PJ website and will be available for you as part of your subscription.If you have an ePaper subscription there will be no change as to how you access your Press and Journal ePaper.The new website is now live. story: We are excited to announce a new home for the Evening Express content online, with a bigger and better website in partnership with The Press and Journal. We have spoken to our readers, and our aim is to deliver you everything that you need to know, together in one place.If you are a subscriber or thinking about joining our digital community, find out what it means for you below.In order to give you access to the news that you need, we have expanded our newsrooms and created dedicated news teams to serve you and our extended local communities across Aberdeen, Aberdeenshire, the Highlands and Islands and the North and North-East of Scotland. We will deliver you more content, live news as it happens, as well as breaking crime news and the latest from court, together in one place. We have also found new ways of telling our stories online, from in-depth investigations through to full- documentaries and podcasts.There is no change to The Press and Journal and the Evening Express newspaper or ePapers. The newspapers will continue to be available for purchase at your local store, delivered to your home, or as an ePaper . We will continue to deliver you the best stories in print, that you have come to expect from the PJ and the Evening Express.Our ePapers are a full replica version of the newspaper, published online,  days a week. You can access the PJ and the Evening Express ePaper via our dedicated ePaper apps where you can save and share stories, access all the paper supplements easily via their dedicated menu and even play interactive puzzles!If you would like to find out more about subscribing to the PJ or the Evening Express ePaper, please contact our Digital News Subscriptions Team on Your subscription to the Press and Journal will allow you to access all of the Evening Express stories which are now available on the PJ website. All of the best Evening Express content, including columnists and football analysis will now appear on the PJ website and will be available for you as part of your subscription.If you have an ePaper subscription there will be no change as to how you access your Press and Journal ePaper.The new website is now live. We have spoken to our readers, and our aim is to deliver you everything that you need to know, together in one place.If you are a subscriber or thinking about joining our digital community, find out what it means for you below.In order to give you access to the news that you need, we have expanded our newsrooms and created dedicated news teams to serve you and our extended local communities across Aberdeen, Aberdeenshire, the Highlands and Islands and the North and North-East of Scotland. We will deliver you more content, live news as it happens, as well as breaking crime news and the latest from court, together in one place. We have also found new ways of telling our stories online, from in-depth investigations through to full- documentaries and podcasts.There is no change to The Press and Journal and the Evening Express newspaper or ePapers. The newspapers will continue to be available for purchase at your local store, delivered to your home, or as an ePaper . We will continue to deliver you the best stories in print, that you have come to expect from the PJ and the Evening Express.Our ePapers are a full replica version of the newspaper, published online,  days a week.
